entry.title: Breaking Down Language Barriers: Machine Translation Now Available for SAP Activate road map viewer
entry.content:
Hello and welcome!

We're excited to share a major update that we believe will make your experience with SAP Activate even better. We know how important it is to have clear, accessible resources, and that's why we’ve introduced a new feature to help you work more efficiently, no matter what language you speak.

Introducing Machine-Translated SAP Activate road maps

Navigating an SAP Activate implementation road map in a language you’re not completely comfortable with can be a challenge.

That's why we're thrilled to announce that we've added a Machine Translation feature to the SAP Activate road map Viewer Portal. This new capability, powered by SAP's own AI-enabled machine translations from SAP Translation Hub, will help you overcome linguistic barriers so you can focus on what matters most: planning your implementation and understanding best practices.

Whether you're starting a brand-new project or exploring the latest features, having the information in your preferred language will make it easier to understand complex instructions and troubleshoot issues quickly.

How to get started

Ready to try it out? It's simple:

  1. Log in to SAP for Me or SAP Activate road map Viewer Portal.
  2. Go to My Settings.
  3. Choose your preferred language from the list of Languages that SAP for Me supports:
    • English
    • German
    • Chinese
    • Korean
    • Japanese
    • French
    • Spanish
    • Portuguese
    • Italian

SAP For Me Settings

Once you’ve done this, the road maps in SAP Activate will be displayed in your chosen language.

Currently, we support machine translation for these Roadmaps:

SAP Activate for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (3-system landscape)

SAP Activate for SAP Cloud ERP Private - New Implementation

SAP Activate for SAP Cloud ERP Private - System Conversion

SAP Activate for SAP Cloud ERP Private - Selective Data Transition

SAP Activate SAP Cloud ERP Private - Upgrade

SAP Activate for SAP Business Technology Platform

SAP Activate for Conversion of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2-system to 3-system landscape

SAP Activate for New Cloud Implementations (Public Cloud-General)

Your feedback is crucial

We know that machine translation isn't always perfect. That's why your feedback is so important! If you find a translation that could be better, please let us know. Just click the Feedback button at the top of the SAP Activate road map Viewer page and select "Translation errors" as the category.

Feedback

Your input will help us refine the translations and ensure the content is helpful for everyone. We can't wait to hear what you think!

 

Please share your feedback with us!

Your SAP Activate Team

entry.title: SAP S4 HANA Public Cloud ODATA V4 API throwing 403 error blocked by UCON
entry.content:
We are facing an issue with one ODAT V4  UI type service in S4 HANA public cloud system. Use case is: We have Developed a custom ODATA V4 UI service and created a Fiori elements based UI app in BAS and deployed on BTP Workzone. We have tested this app in Dev system and everything working as expected. But when we transported the same custom service and UI app to Quality system, the ODATA V4 service is throwing 403 Forbidden UCON Blocked error when we try to load the App or load the metadata from browser as well. 

 

Anyone has worked on ODATA V4 UI  API and created a UI app using BTP BAS? Your inputs are highly appreciated. Thanks.

SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA

entry.title: Re: SAP DIGITAL MANUFACTURING - TRANSFER ERP PERSONNEL NUMBER in COMPLETE SFC - YELD CONFIRM
entry.content:
Hi Antonio,

just to make sure I understood your enquiry.

1. You have one SFC under a order with a quantity of larger then 1

2. The user enters the POD with a badge in advance

3. You are entering a partial quantity confirmation means the SFC will be at operation 1 and operation 2 since relaxed routing is active

4. Your issue: You want the Badge Number of the respective user confirmed as the personel number within the quantity confirmation, right?

You said the following "... a partial quantity using API /sfcs/complete". Does this means that you are using the API to confirm quantities or do you use a production process which is calling the "Complete SFCs" business service? And why are you not using the normal SFC Complete? But regardless of that, I think you can't map the "batch" number easily into the "PERS_NO" field of the workflow you are using for the confirmation. I was taking a look into the CPI to see if the batch number is available to be mapped but unfortunately thats not the case. 

Cheers,

Kevin

entry.title: Performance Rethought: LLM Standards in Embedded AI
entry.content:
🚀From Milliseconds to Minutes: Why Everything You Know About Performance is About to Change

Gone are the days when 200ms was considered slow. Welcome to the era where waiting 10 seconds for an AI response isn't just acceptable—it's revolutionary. If you're building LLM-powered applications and still thinking in traditional performance metrics, you're not just behind the curve—you're on the wrong curve entirely.

This isn't your typical performance optimization guide. It's a deep dive into the uncharted waters of AI application development, where the rules have fundamentally changed and the playbook is still being written. Buckle up for a comprehensive technical journey that will reshape how you think about performance, quality, and user experience in the age of embedded AI.

⚡What You're About to Discover:

  • Why traditional KPIs are not just inadequate—they're misleading
  • The hidden variables that actually control LLM performance (spoiler: it's not your server specs)
  • How to make 15-second responses feel faster than 3-second ones
  • The monitoring strategies that separate successful AI products from failed experiments
  • Real-world approaches to testing systems that give different answers to the same question

Ready to navigate the new reality of multi-second interactions and redefine what "good performance" actually means? Let's dive in.

Table of Contents

 

Section

Topic

1

The LLM Performance Reality Check

2

Redefining Performance Standards

3

Mastering Non-Deterministic Systems

4

User Experience for Multi-Second Interactions

5

Technical Implementation Guidelines

6

Modern Monitoring Approaches

7

Cost-Performance Optimization

8

Quality Assurance Strategies

9

Future-Proofing Your Architecture

10

Building Sustainable AI Products

 

1. The LLM Performance Reality Check

The world of application performance has fundamentally shifted. Traditional applications where we optimized for 50ms, 200ms, or 400ms response times have given way to AI-powered systems where meaningful interactions can take 5, 10, or even 30+ seconds. This isn't a performance problem to solve – it's a new paradigm to design around.

Based on experience from Gen AI POC development and performance engineering work, the fundamental challenge isn't making LLM applications faster – it's redefining what "acceptable performance" means when core computation happens in external systems beyond our control. Every LLM request is essentially an external API call with inherently unpredictable response times.

This reality requires a complete rethink of product standards, user experience design, and performance measurement approaches. The community needs practical guidelines for navigating this new landscape while still delivering value to users.

2. Redefining Performance Standards

Traditional performance KPIs don't translate effectively to LLM-based applications. While conventional applications target 1-3 seconds for simple tasks or maximum 5 seconds for complex operations, AI-powered applications operate in a fundamentally different performance landscape.

Key Performance Variables

The factors that significantly impact LLM response times include:

Model Selection: Different models (GPT-4, Claude, LLaMA variants, or specialized models) have distinct performance profiles. Smaller models might deliver responses in 2-3 seconds for simple tasks, while larger models could require 10-15 seconds for the same query.

Token Economics: Both input and output token counts dramatically affect response time. A prompt with 1,000 tokens might take twice as long as a 500-token prompt with identical model configurations.

Infrastructure and Deployment: Provisioned deployments vs. on-demand services can show 3-5x performance variance. Provisioned deployments might consistently deliver 2-second responses, while shared infrastructure could require 8-10 seconds during peak usage.

Prompt Complexity: Compute-bound tasks (mathematical reasoning, code generation) vs. memory-bound tasks (text completion, summarization) exhibit different performance characteristics.

Additional Variables to Consider:

  • Geographic proximity to inference endpoints
  • Network latency and bandwidth constraints
  • Concurrent request load on shared infrastructure
  • Model warming and cold start effects
  • Request queuing and throttling mechanisms

Setting Realistic Performance Standards

An effective approach should focus on business context rather than arbitrary time limits:

A. Production-Like Testing: Prefer testing with realistic data volumes and production-equivalent infrastructure rather than development environment metrics.

B. Scenario-Based Benchmarking: The approach should establish performance expectations based on specific user scenarios. Creative writing assistants might justify 10-second responses, while customer service chatbots need sub-3-second replies.

C. Perceived Performance Priority: Streaming responses can make a 10-second interaction feel more responsive than a 3-second batch response, making user perception more valuable than raw response time metrics.

3. Mastering Non-Deterministic Systems

Traditional software testing assumes deterministic outputs – the same input should always produce the same output. LLM applications fundamentally challenge this assumption, requiring new approaches to testing and validation.

Common Variability Patterns

In POC development and use case testing, identical prompts commonly produce:

  • Varying response lengths (200 words vs. 500 words for the same request)
  • Different accuracy levels under system load
  • Inconsistent formatting and structure
  • Variable response times even with identical infrastructure

A practical example: document-based GenAI use cases under normal load might provide detailed, accurate analysis. During stress testing with concurrent requests, the same system might deliver superficial analysis and occasionally generate information not present in the trained dataset.

Testing Approach for Non-Deterministic Systems

A. Baseline Establishment: The preferred approach involves sending identical prompts 10-20 times to understand natural variation ranges before implementing load testing.

B.Quality Metrics Under Load: Performance testing should encompass maintaining output quality as system load increases, not just response speed.

C.Response Validation Frameworks: Teams should implement pattern-matching approaches to validate that responses contain expected key elements, even when exact wording varies.

4. User Experience for Multi-Second Interactions

The shift from millisecond to multi-second interactions has forced a complete rethink of user experience design. Users have different expectations when they know they're interacting with AI, but those expectations need to be carefully managed.

Streaming: The Game Changer

Implementing streaming responses represents the most impactful UX improvement for LLM applications. When users see tokens appearing in real-time, a 15-second response feels interactive rather than sluggish. The psychological effect is significant – users perceive the system as "thinking out loud" rather than being unresponsive.

Managing Expectations Through Design

Transparency works better than trying to hide the AI nature of interactions:

  • Progress Indicators: The preferable approach uses contextual messages like "Analyzing your document..." or "Generating recommendations..." instead of generic loading spinners
  • Time Estimates: When possible, provide rough time estimates based on request complexity
  • Cancellation Options: Long-running requests should include escape mechanisms

Continuous Feedback Mechanisms

LLM applications require different feedback approaches than traditional immediate-response applications:

  • Real-time streaming for immediate engagement
  • Intermediate results for complex multi-step tasks
  • Post-response quality feedback to improve future interactions

5. Technical Implementation Guidelines

LLM-based applications require fundamentally different monitoring approaches than traditional applications. These systems should integrate with APM tools like Dynatrace for comprehensive observability alongside specialized LLM metrics.

Understanding the LLM Processing Pipeline

LLM processing involves distinct stages, each with different optimization strategies:

  • Queue Time: Duration requests wait before processing begins
  • Prefill Stage: Initial input prompt processing (compute-bound)
  • Decode/Inference Stage: Token-by-token generation (memory-bound)
  • Inter-token Latency: Time between individual token generations

Tools like vLLM provide visibility into these stages for performance optimization.

Hardware Constraint Considerations

Based on experience, hardware limitations often become bottlenecks before software optimizations matter:

GPU Power Limits: Systems might hit power limits (e.g., 350W), causing performance throttling that reduces throughput by 40-50%. DCGM metrics monitoring becomes essential for identifying these constraints.

Memory Bandwidth: The memory-bound nature of decode phases means GPU memory bandwidth often limits token generation speed more than compute capacity.

Thermal Throttling: Extended high-load operations can cause thermal throttling, leading to unpredictable performance degradation.

Infrastructure Monitoring Requirements

Effective LLM monitoring should consider both application-level and hardware-level metrics:

Application Metrics:

  • Time to First Token (TTFT)
  • Token generation rate
  • Queue depth and wait times
  • Request completion rates

Hardware Metrics:

  • GPU utilization and clock frequencies
  • Power consumption and thermal status
  • Memory utilization patterns
  • Network I/O for distributed inference

6. Modern Monitoring Approaches

Traditional APM tools require extension for LLM applications. The approach should encompass comprehensive observability beyond standard metrics.

Multi-Dimensional Performance Tracking

LLM performance requires tracking multiple dimensions simultaneously:

  1. Latency Distribution: P50, P90, P95, and P99 percentiles rather than just average response time
  2. Quality Degradation: Response accuracy and completeness under various load conditions
  3. Resource Utilization: Both compute and financial resource consumption
  4. User Satisfaction: Direct feedback correlation with performance metrics

Advanced Alerting Strategies

Standard latency-based alerting doesn't suit LLM applications. Teams should develop:

  • Quality-based alerts: Triggered when response accuracy drops below acceptable thresholds
  • Cost threshold alerts: Activated when per-request costs exceed budget parameters
  • Capacity planning alerts: Indicating when queue times suggest scaling needs

7. Cost-Performance Optimization

LLM applications present unique cost-performance challenges. Unlike traditional applications where better hardware improves performance, AI systems face complex cost-performance matrices requiring strategic optimization.

LLM Economics Considerations

Model Selection Impact: Premium models might provide better quality but cost 10-20x more than alternatives like GPT-3.5-turbo or GPT-4o-mini for similar tasks. Performance differences might be marginal for many use cases.

Token Optimization: Prompt engineering for token efficiency improves both performance and cost. Reducing input prompts from 1,000 to 500 tokens speeds responses and halves costs.

Deployment Model Economics: Provisioned throughput models offer predictable performance but require minimum commitments. Pay-per-use models provide flexibility with performance variability.

Cost-Performance Optimization Approach

A.Use Case Classification: Not every interaction requires the most powerful model

  1. Dynamic Model Selection: Route simple queries to faster, more economical models
  2. Caching Strategies: Implement intelligent caching for repeated or similar queries
  3. Load Balancing: Distribute requests across different model deployments based on cost and performance requirements

8. Quality Assurance Strategies

Quality assurance for LLM applications requires a fundamentally different approach than traditional software testing. Functional testing, performance testing, and quality testing are inseparably intertwined.

QA Approach for Non-Deterministic Systems

Behavioral Testing: Instead of testing for exact outputs, focus on behavioral consistency. The system should maintain appropriate tone, accuracy level, and response structure across different scenarios.

Load-Quality Correlation: System load often impacts response quality before affecting response time. Quality degradation can serve as an early warning sign of infrastructure stress.

Regression Testing: Traditional regression testing doesn't work when outputs vary naturally. The approach should test for maintained capability rather than identical outputs.

Quality Metrics to Track

  • Response Relevance: How well does the output address the input query?
  • Factual Accuracy: For knowledge-based tasks, accuracy under various load conditions
  • Consistency: Variation in response quality for similar inputs
  • Safety and Appropriateness: Maintaining safety guardrails under stress

9. Future-Proofing Your Architecture

Building LLM applications requires planning for constant change in this rapidly evolving field.

Technical Architecture Considerations

Model Agnostic Design: Build applications that can switch between different LLM providers and models without major architectural changes.

Scalable Infrastructure: The infrastructure needs to handle both current workloads and rapid scaling as user adoption grows.

Monitoring and Observability: Comprehensive logging and monitoring become even more critical when dealing with external AI services.

Business Planning for AI Applications

Cost Modeling: LLM costs can scale unpredictably with user growth. Build in cost monitoring and alerting from day one.

Performance SLA Management: Set realistic expectations with stakeholders about AI application performance characteristics.

Continuous Optimization: Unlike traditional applications that reach stable performance, LLM applications require ongoing optimization as models, infrastructure, and usage patterns evolve.

10. Building Sustainable AI Products

Success requires embracing the fundamental differences rather than trying to force AI into traditional application paradigms.

Core Recommendations

A. Accept the Performance Reality: Multi-second response times aren't bugs to fix – they're characteristics to design around.

B. Focus on Business Value: The question isn't whether a 10-second response is fast enough, but whether the value provided justifies the wait for specific use cases.

C. Invest in User Experience: Streaming, progress indication, and expectation management are more important than raw performance optimization.

D. Build Comprehensive Monitoring: Traditional metrics aren't sufficient. Teams need visibility into quality, cost, and user satisfaction alongside performance.

E. Plan for Variability: Both performance and quality will vary. Design systems that gracefully handle this variability rather than trying to eliminate it.

F. Gather Direct User Feedback: In the absence of standard benchmarks, user satisfaction becomes the ultimate performance metric.

The LLM application landscape continues evolving rapidly. These guidelines represent practical approaches based on current experience, but practices will continue evolving as the technology matures. The key is building systems that can adapt to this evolution while delivering consistent value to users.

Organizations that succeed will embrace the unique characteristics of AI applications rather than trying to make them behave like traditional software. The future belongs to products that harness AI power while managing its constraints thoughtfully and transparently.

These insights draw on hands-on experience from Gen AI development and performance engineering. By sharing practical learnings, the community can collectively advance in building robust LLM-based applications.

What challenges have you faced in your own use cases, and which approaches have proven most effective? Sharing experiences and solutions will help the broader community navigate this evolving space.

entry.title: Onboarding 2.0 - Modify Task Due Date
entry.content:
We would like to modify the due dates assigned to new hires in Onboarding to be based on when we initiate onboarding versus being related to the new hires start date.

Example:

  1. We extend an offer to a candidate 9/1/25 with an anticipated start date of 10/1/25
  2. Candidate accepts offer 9/2/25.
  3. We initiate Onboarding 9/3/25.
  4. We would like all new hire Onboarding tasks to be completed within 2 days of initiating Onboarding.  In this example, all new hire Onboarding tasks should be completed by 9/5/25.

Has anyone had any luck assigning due dates that are not related to the start date?  It seems to me that due dates can only be built based on the start date, for example, 5 days before start date.

Cost assignment to project / WBS from manual journals / service postingsPartially supportedCertain manual journals do not allow project/WBS assignment; restrictions exist for activity types / cost center categories.KBA 2864151SAP KBA 2864151
Time recording → project work packages / WBS elementsSupportedStandard time recording works; limitation is mainly around reversals and duplicate postings from multiple sources.Learning JourneyLearning.sap.com Time Recording
Purchase Requisition / PO account assignment “Project (P)” + Cost CenterIssue / BugWhen copying PR lines, old project assignments may remain → double assignment (Cost Center + Project).KBA 3542501SAP KBA 3542501
Default cost object “Project” in expense reportsAvailableCan default project instead of cost center in employee settings (“My Data / Personalize”).KBA 1971120SAP KBA 1971120

 

  • The duplication likely arises because the initial time entry (from SuccessFactors) is posted, and then another entry (from Excel upload) also posts cost. Since there is no auto‐reversal for the first intercompany type entry, both remain active.

  • If the system disallows project assignment on the reversing entry or offsetting entry (because of manual journal / rule restrictions), then you can’t correct it correctly in the project dimension.

 

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos. This motivates me to serve you better.
Appreciate your feedback. Used GenAI.
Thanks,
Divyesh

entry.title: SAP OData to MCP Server running on BTP
entry.content:
Transform your SAP S/4HANA or ECC system into a conversational AI interface by exposing all OData services as dynamic MCP tools. This enables natural language interactions with your ERP data:

  • "Show me 10 banks" → Automatically queries the Bank entity with $top=10
  • "Update bank with ID 1 to have street number 5" → Executes PATCH operation on Bank entity
  • "Create a new customer with name John Doe" → Performs POST to Customer entity
  • "List all purchase orders from this week" → Applies $filter for date range on PurchaseOrder entity

Prerequisite

CloudFoundry CLI installed: https://docs.cloudfoundry.org/cf-cli/install-go-cli.html 

BTP Account with CloudFoundry active and a space:

Cloud Connector with principal propagation

Install

Go to the GitHub repository: https://github.com/lemaiwo/btp-sap-odata-to-mcp-server

Click on the green button “Code” and copy the url:

git clone https://github.com/lemaiwo/btp-sap-odata-to-mcp-server.git
cd btp-sap-odata-to-mcp-server

Copy the example.env file into a .env file and configure it to your needs, find more information in the Configure and Options section

npm run build:btp
cf login -a <cf api endpoint of BTP>
npm run deploy:btp

Once deployed, you'll find it in the list of applications in BTP CloudFoundry:

 

Configure

Create two destinations:

  • one with principal propagation to have SSO which will be used to executed OData queries with the user JWT 
  • one with a technical user that is used while starting the server to scan the OData services of the system and already preload the metadata

Technical destination:

Destination with principal propagation:

 

Copy the .env.example file to .env and configure it as follows to have the recommended settings but replace the ODATA_SERVICE_PATTERNS with your preferred selection:

SAP_DISCOVERY_DESTINATION_NAME=SAP_SYSTEM_TECH
SAP_EXECUTION_DESTINATION_NAME=SAP_SYSTEM_SSO
# SAP_DESTINATION_NAME=your-own-destination

LOG_LEVEL=debug

# OData Service Discovery Configuration Examples
# Method 1: Allow all services (use * or 'true')
ODATA_ALLOW_ALL=false

# Method 2: Specify service patterns (supports glob patterns)
# Comma-separated list of patterns
ODATA_SERVICE_PATTERNS=*TASKPROCESSING*,*BOOK*,*FLIGHT*,*TRAVEL*,*TRVEXP*,*TRAVELAGENCY*,*TRAVELAGENCYSRV*,*TRAVELAPPROVALS*,*TRAVELAPPROVALS_SRV*,*ZBP*,*ZTRANSPORT*,*ZBC_UI_PARAM_E_CDS*

# Method 3: Use JSON array for more complex patterns
# ODATA_SERVICE_PATTERNS=["ZBP*", "ZTRANSPORT*", "/^Z.*_CDS$/"]

# Method 4: Use regex patterns (enclose in forward slashes)
# ODATA_SERVICE_PATTERNS=/^Z(BP|TRANSPORT).*/

# Exclusion patterns (services to exclude even if they match inclusion patterns)
ODATA_EXCLUSION_PATTERNS=*_TEST*,*_TEMP*

# Maximum number of services to discover (prevents system overload)
ODATA_MAX_SERVICES=50

# Discovery mode: 'all', 'whitelist', 'regex'
ODATA_DISCOVERY_MODE=whitelist

Use

Copy the url of the application

Go to your AI Agent/LLM, eg.: Claude AI desktop, open tools and click on Manage connectors:

Click on "Add custom connector" :

Give the MCP server a name and paste the url of the application in BTP with “/mcp” added to it:

It might take some time before it is shown. For some reason, Claude Dekstop first try’s to connect without authentication and then takes some time before showing the system:

After some time it should become visible:

Once the system is visible, you can click on the connect button. This will redirect you to BTP to login. First time it might ask you to login to claude, after that it should give you the sap login or your corporate idp, if not, try clicking a second time on connect:

Once authenticated, you’ll find your SAP system in the set of tools:

Start asking questions:

Options

A key capability is deploying the MCP Server to different spaces within the same subaccount. This lets you set up multiple MCP servers with different configurations. For example, you can configure an MCP server for each SAP system in your landscape, or set up one for each domain — such as one MCP server for all HR OData services, another for all Materials Management (MM) OData services, and so on.

Core Configuration

Configuration Option

Description

Example Values

Notes

SAP_DISCOVERY_DESTINATION_NAME

SAP destination for service discovery (uses technical user)

SAP_SYSTEM_TECH

Used for metadata operations

SAP_EXECUTION_DESTINATION_NAME

SAP destination for data operations (uses JWT forwarding for SSO)

SAP_SYSTEM_SSO

Used for actual data access with user context

SAP_DESTINATION_NAME

Single destination for both discovery and execution

SAP_SYSTEM

Legacy option for backward compatibility

MCP_TOOL_REGISTRY_TYPE

Defines how tools are organized in the registry

hierarchical (default)
flat

IMPORTANT: hierarchical exposes all OData services as just 4 tools. flat exposes EVERY CRUD operation for EACH entity as separate tools. While this can exceed limits with many services, flat mode can be beneficial for small, focused deployments

LOG_LEVEL

Controls the verbosity of application logging

error, warn, info, debug

Default is info

DISABLE_READ_ENTITY_TOOL

Disables ReadEntity tool registration

true, false (default)

Useful for performance with large datasets

 

⚠️CRITICAL CONFIGURATION NOTE: The MCP_TOOL_REGISTRY_TYPE setting has a major impact on tool exposure:

  • hierarchical mode (recommended for most cases):
      - Exposes all OData services through just 4 unified tools
      - Keeps the tool count manageable regardless of service count
      - Requires agents to first discover services, then entities

  • flat mode:
      - Creates individual tools for EVERY CRUD operation for EACH entity
      - Can quickly exceed system limits with many services (hundreds/thousands of tools)
      - Significantly increases token consumption
      - HOWEVER: Can be advantageous for small, focused deployments (1-2 services)
        where direct tool names like "Create_BusinessPartner" or "Update_SalesOrder"
        make it easier for agents to find and use the right tool without discovery steps

 

OData Service Discovery Configuration

Configuration Option

Description

Example Values

Notes

ODATA_ALLOW_ALL

Allow discovery of all available services

true, false (default)

Use * or true to enable

ODATA_SERVICE_PATTERNS

Specify which services to include using patterns

See examples section

Supports multiple pattern formats

ODATA_EXCLUSION_PATTERNS

Services to exclude even if they match inclusion patterns

*_TEST*,*_TEMP*

Comma-separated list

ODATA_MAX_SERVICES

Maximum number of services to discover

50 (example)

Prevents system overload

ODATA_DISCOVERY_MODE

Controls how service discovery works

all, whitelist, regex

Determines pattern matching behavior

 

Service Pattern Examples

Pattern Type

Example

Description

Glob Patterns

*TASKPROCESSING*,*BOOK*

Use wildcards (*) to match multiple services

Specific Services

*TRAVEL*,*TRAVELAGENCY*

Target specific service names

Prefix Matching

ZBP*,ZTRANSPORT*

Match services starting with specific prefixes

JSON Array

["ZBP*", "ZTRANSPORT*"]

Complex patterns in JSON format

Regex Patterns

/^Z(BP|TRANSPORT).*/

Regular expressions in forward slashes

 

Configuration Examples

Example 1: Enterprise Setup with Separate Authentication

Use Case: Large enterprise SAP landscape with strict security requirements

# Separate destinations for security
SAP_DISCOVERY_DESTINATION_NAME=SAP_ECC_TECH_USER
SAP_EXECUTION_DESTINATION_NAME=SAP_ECC_SSO

# Use hierarchical mode for many services
MCP_TOOL_REGISTRY_TYPE=hierarchical

# Whitelist specific business services
ODATA_DISCOVERY_MODE=whitelist
ODATA_SERVICE_PATTERNS=*SALESORDER*,*PURCHASEORDER*,*BUSINESSPARTNER*,*MATERIAL*
ODATA_EXCLUSION_PATTERNS=*_TEST*,*_TEMP*,*_DEV*
ODATA_MAX_SERVICES=100

# Production logging
LOG_LEVEL=info

Example 2: Development Environment - All Services

Use Case: Development/sandbox environment where developers need access to all services

# Single destination for simplicity
SAP_DESTINATION_NAME=SAP_DEV_SYSTEM

# Hierarchical for many services
MCP_TOOL_REGISTRY_TYPE=hierarchical

# Allow all services in dev
ODATA_ALLOW_ALL=true
ODATA_EXCLUSION_PATTERNS=*_ARCHIVE*
ODATA_MAX_SERVICES=200

# Debug logging for development
LOG_LEVEL=debug

Example 3: Focused HR Service - Flat Mode

Use Case: Small MCP server dedicated to HR operations with direct tool access

# HR-specific destination
SAP_DESTINATION_NAME=SAP_HR_SYSTEM

# Flat mode for direct tool access
MCP_TOOL_REGISTRY_TYPE=flat

# Only HR-related services
ODATA_DISCOVERY_MODE=whitelist
ODATA_SERVICE_PATTERNS=*EMPLOYEE*,*ORGUNIT*,*TIMESHEET*
ODATA_MAX_SERVICES=5

# Standard logging
LOG_LEVEL=info

# Note: This creates tools like:

# - Create_Employee

# - Update_TimeSheet

# - Delete_OrgUnit

# Making it easy for agents to directly use HR operations

 

Example 4: Custom Services with Regex Patterns

Use Case: Organization with custom-developed Z* and Y* services

# Technical user for custom services
SAP_DISCOVERY_DESTINATION_NAME=SAP_CUSTOM_TECH
SAP_EXECUTION_DESTINATION_NAME=SAP_CUSTOM_SSO

# Hierarchical for scalability
MCP_TOOL_REGISTRY_TYPE=hierarchical

# Regex pattern for custom services
ODATA_DISCOVERY_MODE=regex
ODATA_SERVICE_PATTERNS=/^[ZY].*_SRV$/
ODATA_EXCLUSION_PATTERNS=*_OLD*,*_BACKUP*
ODATA_MAX_SERVICES=75

# Info level for production
LOG_LEVEL=info
DISABLE_READ_ENTITY_TOOL=false

Example 5: Multi-Domain Setup with Complex Patterns

Use Case: Multiple business domains with specific service requirements

# Separate auth for compliance
SAP_DISCOVERY_DESTINATION_NAME=SAP_PROD_METADATA
SAP_EXECUTION_DESTINATION_NAME=SAP_PROD_USER_AUTH

# Hierarchical for large service count
MCP_TOOL_REGISTRY_TYPE=hierarchical

# Complex pattern matching using JSON array
ODATA_SERVICE_PATTERNS=["*FI_*", "*CO_*", "*MM_*", "*SD_*", "/^Z(FI|CO|MM|SD).*/"]
ODATA_EXCLUSION_PATTERNS=*_TEST*,*_TMP*,*_BCK*,*_DECOMMISSIONED*
ODATA_MAX_SERVICES=150

# Standard production settings
LOG_LEVEL=info
DISABLE_READ_ENTITY_TOOL=false

# This configuration covers:

# - Finance (FI) services

# - Controlling (CO) services 

# - Materials Management (MM) services

# - Sales & Distribution (SD) services

# - Custom services for these modules

 

Tool Registry Mode Comparison

Scenario 1: Large SAP Deployment
10 OData services, each with 5 entities:

hierarchical mode: 4 tools total (search, discover, schema, execute)

flat mode: 10 services × 5 entities × 4 CRUD = 200 individual tools ❌ Not recommended

 

Scenario 2: Focused Deployment
1 Business Partner service with 3 entities (Partner, Address, Contact):

hierarchical mode: 4 generic tools (requires discovery steps)

flat mode: 12 specific tools like "Create_BusinessPartner", "Update_Address" ✅ Could be optimal

 

💡RECOMMENDATION:
• Use hierarchical for standard deployments and when exposing multiple services
• Consider flat only for small, focused MCP servers (1-2 services) where you want to keep the MCP server small and optimize for direct tool discovery by agents
• Always exclude test/temporary services in production environments
• Set appropriate ODATA_MAX_SERVICES limits to prevent performance issues

entry.title: Re: How to register work procedures for the next fiscal y...
entry.content:
Hello @ZZ3987 

Thank you for your question.

Answer to question 1: Yes, it is possible to enter planned cost in the item master and then update the work procedure in actual operation. The manage routings for discrete manufacturing and manage master recipes for process industries are maintained through the Fiori apps in public cloud.

Consult Manage Routings & manage master recipes for more details.

Answer to question 2: The steps to register work procedures in public cloud is for you to prepare cost revisions using the validity periods and change numbers. First is to manage routings and assign a change number, then maintain planned standard cost for next year and thereafter, use the mass change routing app or mass maintenance tools for work centers to make a bulk update.

  • Be careful to always ensure that your validity end date of the old routing and valid from date of the new routing do not overlap each other.
  • Make sure you assign different change numbers for each revision cycle auditability.
  • Also ensure you recalculate and test the new cost estimate before you release it.

Consult Change management with change numbers & Manage Material Cost Estimates for more details.

I hope this provides the desired insight. Happy to answer any further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Not able to update Issuing Storage Location - RESLO -...
entry.content:
Hello @Caterina_Bulgar 

Thank you for your question.

You are right, the limitation is a known one in public cloud when using the RAP framework. It currently does not expose the issuing storage location field for stock transfer purchase requisitions with U item category and cannot be set through standard extensibility. You can only work with the fields SAP has listed in the interface.

If RESLo is mandatory for your business, the current workaround is to capture it in a custom field on the PR item. Then use this field for reporting or in follow-on processing logic. Please note that this will not populate the standard RESLO table field in the backend.

You can raise this API gap through the customer influence portal. Alternatively, you can open an incident to request confirmation if RESLO will be released in a future API version.

I hope this provides the desired insight. Happy to answer any further questions.

Best regards

Chris

APIs in Sourcing and Procurement

entry.title: Re: SAP S4 HANA Public Cloud ODATA V4 API throwing 403 er...
entry.content:
Hello @munipkumar 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the Creating Custom Business Objects, Enabling Custom Business Objects & Communication Management links.

To summarise, the error you are receiving is typical when you move a custom OData V4 UI service between systems in public cloud. It is not a coding problem in your service but rather an issue with the unified connectivity whitelisting and communication arrangement setup in your target tenant. The reason is, in DEV your custom service is automatically active because you registered it during development. However, in Q-system, after transport, the service exists but UCON policy block it by default until you release it. This is just a control mechanism for OData services in public cloud.

To resolve that error:

  • Confirm your custom OData V4 service is assigned to a communication scenario, if not, create one.
  • Then create and assign a communication arrangement for your scenario.
  • Thereafter, UCON recognises it as permitted once your service is assigned to a comm arrangement.
  • Finally, authorise by making sure the user in Q-system has a role with the relevant authorisation object and retest your metadata call.

I hope this provides the desired insight. Happy to answer any further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: サポートサイト SAP for Me のユーザ権限付与について
entry.content:
ご質問について、以下の回答をご確認ください。

①ユーザ管理者の設定はユーザ管理者で設定が可能なものでしょうか？
　手順などあればご教授ください。

---＞ユーザー管理者は、他のユーザー管理者を設定することができます。最も簡単な方法は、KBA 1614304 - How to use the Copy Authorization feature for S-user IDs - SAP for Meに従ってユーザー管理者の権限を他のS-userにコピーします。あるいはKBA 1511008 - How to add or change authorizations for a S-User ID - SAP for Meに従ってS-userに個別に権限を付与します。

しかし、SAPユーザー管理のロジックは、S-ユーザーが自分自身が持っている権限しか管理できず、自分が持っていない権限や自分の権限レベルより高い権限を管理することはできないため、一般的には最高権限を持つスーパー管理者によって管理者を管理および作成することを推奨しています。ユーザー管理者は自分よりも高い権限を持つスーパー管理者を作成することはできません。

具体的な情報はKBA 1282821 - How to determine if my S-User ID is a User, Super, or Cloud Administrator - SAP For Meもご参考いただければと思います。


②現在、我々の組織にスーパー管理者が不在であることがわかりました。
　現在のユーザに対してスーパー管理者を設定することは可能でしょうか？
　手順などあればご教授ください。
ご確認よろしくお願いいたします。

---＞上記のご説明どおりにユーザー管理者は自分よりも高い権限を持つスーパー管理者を作成することはできないから、貴社のスーパー管理者は退職する場合、SAP側を依頼してスーパー管理者を作成してください。

entry.title: Re: S4HC 銷售訂單簽核mail通知
entry.content:
Hello @MartinJou 

感谢您的提问。
是的，您可以在公有云环境中为销售订单使用带邮件通知的工作流审批功能。但需注意以下限制和配置要点：
• 系统不会自动向申请人发送邮件。您需要增强工作流场景以实现此功能，具体可通过添加额外的通知步骤，或配置自定义邮件模板并将其分配给工作流结果来实现。
• 输出参数确定功能适用于表单或打印/发票等输出形式。销售订单审批通知不采用此机制，而是通过工作流框架与邮件模板实现。这正是您在OPD中未见销售订单的原因。
详情请参阅 Manage Sales Document Workflows 及 Configuring Email Notification Templates。
希望以上说明能解答您的疑问。欢迎随时提出进一步问题。
此致
敬礼
Chris

Hello @loressap 

Thank you for your question.

There is no direct standard app setting that allows you to sends an automatic alert or email to your purchasing department when a sales order is cancelled. However, there are standard tools you can use to achieve this without having to code.

Consult Situation Handling on how to configure event based alert in your system. See also a previous community question on Situation Handling in Public cloud for further details.

If the cancellation needs an approval or a follow-up action, you can set up a workflow for sales orders.

Please note that you cannot configure this via output parameter determination because it si only for business documents and not for internal process alerts.

Chris

entry.title: Solution Managerの移行について
entry.content:
ご担当者様

現在お客様の環境にてSAPシステムのOS/DBバージョンアップを検討しており、Solution Manager7.2も含まれております。Solution Manager 7.2 はSAP社のサポートを受けるための必須システムであると認識しておりますが、2027年にメンテナンスサポート期限を迎えるためALMへの移行を促す記事がありました。

https://support.sap.com/ja/alm/sap-cloud-alm/transition-to-sap-cloud-alm.html

お客様環境でのSolution Managerの運用方法ですが、EWA出力設定のみとなっており、またS/4HANAのSDCCNから直接EWAをSAP Supportへ送信する設定がされているため実質使用していない状態となっております。使用していないのであれば移行対象から外したいと考えております。

質問内容

  1. Solution ManagerがなくてもEarly Watch Alertが出力できる設定となっていますが、Solution Managerを移行しなくても貴社サポートを受けることは可能でしょうか？それとも2027年までは使用し続けないといけないでしょうか？貴社サポート受ける条件としてSolution Managerを保持していることなのか、EWAさえ取得できればよいのかどちらなのかを知りたいです。
  2. Solution Managerの代わりにALMを導入する場合、ALMは貴社サポートを受けるための必須のサービスでしょうか？それとも使用を推奨しているだけでしょうか？必須でないのであればALMの導入検討を先送りにしたいと考えております。

よろしくお願いいたします。


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Solution Managerの移行について
entry.content:
担当者様

いつもお世話になっております。
お問い合わせにつき、下記回答させていただきます。

質問1.Solution ManagerがなくてもEarly Watch Alertが出力できる設定となっていますが、Solution Managerを移行しなくても貴社サポートを受けることは可能でしょうか？それとも2027年までは使用し続けないといけないでしょうか？貴社サポート受ける条件としてSolution Managerを保持していることなのか、EWAさえ取得できればよいのかどちらなのかを知りたいです。
＝＞お客様のように、EWAをS/4HANAのSDCCNから直接SAPへ送信しており、Solution Managerの他の機能をご利用でない場合、基本的なEWAレポートの送信に関しては、Solution Managerが移行しなくてもSAPサポートを受けられると存じます。
ただし、SAPサポートを受けるための条件は、貴社とSAPとの契約内容によって異なる場合があります。
そのため、契約内容（例：SAP Enterprise Supportなど）に応じて要件が異なる可能性があることから、個別に貴社のSAP営業担当または契約窓口へのご確認をお勧めいたします。
1660069 - How to contact SAP Order Management for contract-related questions or issues
2626344 - Who is the SAP Account Manager for my company?

質問2.Solution Managerの代わりにALMを導入する場合、ALMは貴社サポートを受けるための必須のサービスでしょうか？それとも使用を推奨しているだけでしょうか？必須でないのであればALMの導入検討を先送りにしたいと考えております。
＝＞移行は強く推奨されておりますが、必須のサービスではありません。
もし、より詳細が必要となる場合、恐れ入りますが、貴社のSAP営業・契約担当にご連絡いただき、お気軽にお問い合わせください。

以上、ご確認のほどよろしくお願い申し上げます。
SAP サポート

entry.title: SuccessFactors Crossboarding in mini-EC environment : Insights to consider
entry.content:
Problem statement: The customer were using S/4 HANA as their HRIS system. The customer were also using Employee Central (EC) including Position Management, but without the true flavor EC functionalities such workflows, alerts etc. In this landscape, S/4 HANA is system of truth, and SuccessFactors is a "slave" system with ESS/MSS functionalities being restricted to view only.

The customer were keen to use Crossboarding (XB) to collect additional data and new set of paperwork from their crossboardees.

With SuccessFactors EC being a view only application, the traditional XB processes such as Employer/Employee review were not working. In the employer review the data were not getting displayed at all. In the employee review step also, no data were being displayed where the system was forcing you to update the email address with your personal address. Since no data were being displayed, the system throws and error, and you were unable to move forward.

Note: I did open a SAP ticket and the processor indicated the config looks correct and the ticket need to be escalated to product engineering.

Design thought: After looking at few options, and none of them "really" working that will make it meaningful, I tried the following:

- Created a process variant with only Additional Data Collection and Document Flow. (Since crossboardee are an existing employee, I did not see any real benefit in having personal data collection step).

Crossboarding Process Variant

 - I created a business rule for employment profile selection (Refer to this link to know more about employment profile selection: Employment profile selection )

Business rule - Employee profile selection

 

 (Note: You can use any condition in your if clause. The rule is required to evaluate to true for the rule to trigger)

- The employee profile selection works similar to ReHire. Hence, to support this process, I created the dynamic group

 Note: Since S/4 is the system of truth, the rehire check is done on the S/4 side, when the data is replicated from SuccessFactors.

- I added the employee profile selection in the config step: Manage Data >> Onboarding Configuration.

- Additional data collection and forms were configured and the appropriate business rules were configured.

There are really 2 scenarios to test the Crossboarding scenario:

- When the internal candidate is pushed from Recruiting to Onboarding

- When S/4 updates the employee record with new position info, the updated records is replicated to SuccessFactors. When the appropriate event reason (action/action type in S/4) is used, the system will automatically trigger crossboarding.

Scenario 1:  In this scenario, the internal candidate is processed in Recruiting, accepts offer and Onboarding is initiated. When onboarding is initiated, the record should be available in Employment Profile selection for further processing.

Note: The employment profile selection is really not intuitive. You will see a card in the home page for New Hire Data. You click on the card, and you will see a tab for Employment profile selection.

 

 When you click the Employment Profile Selection option, the crossboarding record is displayed. (This is similar to what we see in ReHire scenarios)

 In the displayed record/page, select the option "Matching Employment". Scroll to the bottom to process the internal hire.  You are required to highlight/select the crossboardee record for the option "Process as internal hire" to be enabled. When you click the option, the record is processed as the Crossboardee.

What I found is, with the employment profile selection, I was able to circumvent/bypass the limitation of employer/employee process step when ESS/MSS were permissioned for view only.

 After completion of the employment profile selection, the crossboardee / internal candidate get a card on their home page to provide additional data to complete the crossboarding process. This is similar to the onboarding experience. 

 

 Scenario 2:  When the updated employee record (with the new position/job information) is replicated from S/4 to SuccessFactors, the business rule automatically triggers crossboarding.

In this scenario, the employer/employee review steps are not initiated. The system automatically triggers additional data collection for the crossboardee to complete.

Note:  In the onboarding dashboard if you have any internal candidate onboarding records (which were pushed prior to this configuration) do not restart the onboarding process. Restarting will automatically trigger crossboarding, but the system will process it as an onboarding process instead of crossboarding.

Conclusion: This design thought, configuration really helped in setting up crossboarding process, making the entire user experience seamless and easy to use.

entry.title: Re: Method for Calculating Amounts to Be Depreciated
entry.content:
Hi @christineha ,

The main issue here is that assignment reference field is blank. You need to ensure that its always filled-up. Inorder to do so there are few controls with different options.

WorkaroundProsCons / Caveats
Ensure consistent Assignment ReferenceIf you make the “Assignment Reference” field mandatory for postings (credit memos, payments) so that it’s never blank, then the open-items will be grouped properly.Might require change to posting processes / user training / validation logic. Some legacy data might still lack that field.
User exit / BADI to populate Assignment Reference automaticallyFor example, when credit memo or unallocated payment is posted, have logic to auto-fill assignment reference (perhaps copy some other field or generate a standard ref).Requires ABAP work / approvals. Need to define what you fill in (must be consistent and meaningful).
Report / Pre-processing to identify missing recordsCreate a report to list open items missing “Assignment Reference” so that they can be corrected manually or through mass update.Still manual overhead.
Modify depreciation calculation logic (if allowed)If the depreciation calculation is custom, change it to ignore the “Assignment Reference” requirement (or treat blank as wildcard) so that all open items are included.If SAP standard logic, modifying it may not be possible or may breach upgrade safety. Need to check with SAP support whether this is allowed.
Use clearing or matching toolsClear or match items so that unallocated / credit notes become allocated and then included.May require business process changes.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos. This motivates me to serve you better.
Appreciate your feedback. Used GenAI.
Thanks,
Divyesh

entry.title: Re: Synchronization between asset master and equipment -...
entry.content:
Hi @Nina_Firus ,

Here are things you should verify, to get the workflow variant working instead of direct sync:

AreaWhat to Check / ConfigureDetails / Notes
Customizing MappingLink Asset Class ↔ Equipment Category / Object Type (table V_ANKAZ_04)Ensure mapping is unique; variant set to “Saving triggers workflow”.
Change Document ObjectsANLA → BUS1022 (Event: EQUITOBECHANGED) EQUI → EQUI (Event: ASSETTOBECHANGED)Must exist in SWEC; ensures changes (e.g., cost center) generate events.
Workflow Event LinkageSWE2 entries link events to workflows (WS3100072/73, WS3100100/101)Verify workflow start events are active and linked.
Workflow DefinitionWS3100072/73 or WS3100100/101Copy & activate SAP sample workflows; adjust to include approval steps.
Task / Agent AssignmentOAWF or PFTCAssign valid agents to tasks (e.g., TS03100055, TS03100039). Ensure agents have proper authorizations.
Equipment Workflow ActivationActivate AA sync in PM customizing“Equipment Workflow → Activate Asset Accounting (Link Object Type with Asset Class)”.
Event Activation in PMActivate workflow event for equipment categoryIf not done, system defaults to direct sync even if workflow chosen.
EnhancementsUser Exit AAPM0001 (per Note 370884)May be required for workflow-based sync; check if active/implemented.
Change Document CreationVerify in CDHDR / CDPOS for Equipment changesEnsure cost center (or relevant fields) trigger change docs, otherwise workflow won’t fire.
Monitoring / TestingUse SWEL (event trace) & workflow logConfirm events fire; if not, debug linkage.
Fallback BehaviorIf workflow config missing, system defaults to direct syncExplains why direct sync always works in your case.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos. This motivates me to serve you better.
Appreciate your feedback. Used GenAI.
Thanks,
Divyesh

Custom CDS View / ExtensionBuild or extend a CDS to join invoice data with tax master tables, exposing tax rate.Flexible, dynamic tax rates; reusable.Requires technical development; Cloud restrictions apply.

entry.title: Checking the Values Passed from SFSF Recruiting to SFSF Onboarding - Customers can check themselves
entry.content:
When you initiate onboarding from recruiting, more often than not, you will encounter issues where record throws an error or not all the mapped data were brought over from recruiting to onboarding.

When that happens typically the onboarding/recruiting consultant will lean on the functionality Suite Integration Test page that is available in Provisioning. Click here to review the suite integration setup functionality in SAP Help 

Provisioning access is available only to certified consultant and is not available to customers. At least till now....

In this blog post, I will show how customers can also access the Suite integration setup with accessing provisioning.

Step 1: Goto Recruiting, and select the recruiting record that you used to initiate onboarding

Candidate application profile

Step 2: Create a duplicate tab Duplicate tab with the same application profile displayed

 Step 3: In the URL, paste this URL: /xi/ui/apitest/pages/getEligibleRecordsTest.xhtml

in the browser URL. You should paste the URL right after: https://hcm41preview.sapsf.com/ (where hcm41 refers to your data center). When you do that, the suite integration setup page is displayed.

Suite integration setup page

Step 3: In the suite integration page, delete every entry before and after the "section"  Get RCM/ONB Data

 Now, delete the line "Get RCM/ONB Data". Ensure there is no blank link before "{" and after "}".

Enter the candidate profile ID in the line "candidateId"

Enter the job application id in the line "appId"

Enter the requisition id in the line "reqId"

You can leave the onboarding Id line blank

 

 Now scroll down the page, and click the option "Get Data from RCM Or ONB"

RCM-ONB response output

 The response will display data for every field you have configured in Recruit to Hire configuration step.

I am confident many HRIS colleagues on the customer side will find this link/blog to be helpful and beneficial

Shoutout: A learned colleague from SAP ONB support team showed me this trick. The colleague is not registered in the community and I am unable to provide proper credits.

entry.title: Risk is now available in SAP Cloud ALM
entry.content:
This Wednesday was the day of a bi-weekly release of features in SAP Cloud ALM, and as I follow the news continuously, I checked the “What’s new” page to see what the news for this release would be. I was happy to find a new app for Risks, which is something that was long awaited. I immediately opened Cloud ALM to check this new app. 

"What's new" page:

AI-Generated:

  • “Risk management ensures SAP projects align with business goals by proactively identifying threats to scope, budget, and timeline.
  • It transforms uncertainty into actionable insights, enabling better decision-making throughout the project lifecycle."

First, I could not find Risks in the Implementation page. I noticed a new icon, a magnifier with an exclamation mark, in the menu bar on the left side of the screen, and it was exactly the one. Clicking on that icon I could see the Risks app and created a new one to test, using the button Create.

 

I noticed that a risk has most of the fields we already use in Additional Information for other objects such as tasks, but it also has some new important fields in the context of risk management, such as Category, Mitigation Strategy and Impact/Probability (which defines the value of field Risk Level). Category and Mitigation Strategy have a list box with pre-defined values. I wonder how flexible the Category field is, since it seems to me that it could be enhanced by each customer. A risk can be assigned to project and timebox, not workstream or team, for instance. But it makes sense as it´s a project risk. But I can assign a responsible and an owner, and tag it. You can set it as a template, and its source when you create it manually is automatically set as manually created. So, I suppose soon that will be risks created from other sources, such as a Quality Gate service. Does it make sense?

Category values: 

Mitigation Strategy values:

From what I could see, the matrix for defining the Risk level based on impact and probability is like that:

The result of my first risk (just a test for this blog) is here:

After creating the risk and adding the relevant information, I could see it in the risks list. There are many filters to be used.

As this seems to be just the beginning of risk management in Cloud ALM, I didn’t find any analytics for that, nor the possibility of uploading in mass. I only found the download for analysis. Let’s follow the roadmap and wait for the next releases.

To add the Risk app in your Implementation page, go to App finder and look for it below Implementation. Flag it. In my example below I edited the Implementation page to add the app in the Design, Build, Test and Deploy section.

 

 After that you will see the app. 

Looking forward for the next steps retated to risk management, improvements to this app and analytics, and more information from the Cloud ALM team about it.

entry.title: 5C Framework for SAP Integrated Business Planning Data Validation Strategy
entry.content:
Why Data Quality in SAP IBP?

The success of SAP IBP hinges on the availability of quality data from all relevant sources across the organization. Without this foundation of high-quality data, the collaborative and cross-functional nature of IBP will be severely hampered, leading to flawed insights, poor decisions, and an ineffective planning process that fails to deliver the expected business benefits.

Therefore, organizations implementing SAP IBP must prioritize data quality initiatives as a critical component of their implementation and ongoing operations to ensure that they can leverage the full potential of the integrated planning platform. This often involves establishing data governance processes, data quality and validation routines, and ongoing monitoring of data quality across all the heterogeneous systems and departments.

I, as an IBP solution architect and consultant, have seen data quality impact on various functions and across all levels.

1. Accurate Forecasting and Demand Planning:

  • IBP heavily relies on accurate demand forecasts to plan production, inventory, and supply chain activities.
  • Poor data quality in historical sales data, market trends, or customer information will lead to inaccurate forecasts, resulting in either overstocking (leading to waste and costs) or understocking (leading to lost sales and customer dissatisfaction).

2. Reliable Supply Planning:

  • Accurate demand forecasts and reliable data on current inventory levels, lead times, and supplier capabilities are essential for effective supply planning.
  • Inaccurate data in these areas can lead to production delays, material shortages, and increased costs.

3. Effective Financial Planning:

  • IBP integrates financial planning with operational plans. Accurate financial data, including costs, revenues, and profitability, is crucial for making sound financial decisions.
  • Poor data quality can lead to inaccurate financial projections and budgets, impacting the overall financial health of the organization.

4. Informed Decision-Making:

  • IBP aims to provide a holistic view of the business, enabling informed decision- making across different departments.
  • If the underlying data is inaccurate, incomplete, or inconsistent, the insights derived from IBP will be flawed, leading to poor strategic and operational decisions.

5. Seamless Collaboration:

  • IBP fosters collaboration among different departments. Consistent and reliable data ensures that all stakeholders are working with the same information, facilitating effective communication and alignment.
  • Data quality issues can create friction and mistrust among teams, hindering the collaborative nature of IBP.

6. Performance Measurement and Improvement:

  •  IBP involves monitoring key performance indicators (KPIs) to track progress and identify areas for improvement.
  • Accurate data is essential for measuring performance accurately and identifying the root causes of any issues. Poor data quality can lead to misleading performance metrics and ineffective improvement initiatives.

Data quality is paramount for IBP success. Without high quality data, the benefits of IBP cannot be fully realized, and the organization risks making poor decisions that can negatively impact its bottom line and overall performance.

 

5C Framework for SAP IBP Data Validation

The proposed 5Cs are the core traits which determine whether the data is fit for the SAP IBP planning purpose. By adhering to these 5C's, organizations can improve their data quality, leading to more reliable insights, better decision-making, and increased operational efficiency. It is important to note that maintaining high data quality is an ongoing process that requires continuous monitoring and improvement.

  1. Conformity
  2. Consistency
  3. Completeness
  4. Comprehensiveness
  5. Concurrency

Figure 1: 5Cs of Data Quality Framework

1.      Conformity

This aspect of the SAP IBP data quality ensures that data adheres to predefined rules and standards regarding format, type, and size.

  1. Case for the predefined rules: In SAP IBP there are predefined special characters which cannot be used. (Refer to SAP note: 2453887)

Figure 2: SAP Note 2453887 listing restricted characters

b. Case for the format, type, and size: In SAP IBP, each attribute that exists has a format, type and size associated. All the value must comply by the formats, types, and sizes otherwise there is a risk of the job failure with fatal error.

FORMAT TYPESIZE
NVARCHAR (with/without Only Upper Case)  Character Length (max length up to 450)
DECIMAL    18,6
INTEGER      Whole Number
TIMESTAMP        YYYYMMDD hh:mm:ss.000

Table 1: SAP IBP Format Types and Sizes

2.      Consistency

This aspect of the SAP IBP data quality ensures uniformity, coherency, and avoidance of contradictions across different data sources, planning areas, data objects and time periods. Consistency ensures that information is uniform and comparable throughout the organization. However, when SAP IBP receives data from multiple sources such as ERP systems, data warehouses, cloud-based data lakes, third-party systems, home-grown applications, production planning system, transport planning system and planners' Excel sheets, maintaining data consistency becomes key area to focus on. This diversity of data sources, if ignored, can lead to discrepancies in data formats, definitions, and quality, potentially compromising the accuracy of SAP IBP's planning processes.

To ensure consistency in master Data SAP IBP provides some in-build checks which must be configured like attribute checks and mandatory attributes.

Figure 3: IBP Master Data object consistency checks with attribute checks

For IBP transactional data, we can ensure consistency by adding a mandatory attribute from compound master data in planning level for the key figure. Such configuration avoids inconsistent transactional data flowing into the system.

Figure 4: IBP mandatory attribute used in base planning level of key figures

It is important to understand that SAP IBP does not inherently guarantee consistency within object hierarchies such as Product, Customer, and Location hierarchies. Therefore, the Customer and System Integrator's consultants must collaboratively develop a strategy to ensure consistency in parent-child relationships (1:N cardinality) for hierarchical data objects. This proactive approach is crucial for accurate aggregation and disaggregation, enabling effective and actionable insights.

Figure 5: IBP Data Hierarchy with Parent Child relationship

To ensure the correct parent-child relationships, one of the approaches is to extract a parent-child combination in excel sheet and create a pivot table on unique records. All children must have single parent otherwise aggregation and disaggregation will be wrong, leading to wrong planning results.

3.      Completeness

The completeness of data refers to the state where all the necessary and relevant data points required for the specific planning process and the overall IBP framework are present and available within the system. It means that there are no significant gaps or missing pieces of information that hinder the ability to perform accurate analysis, generate reliable plan and make informed decisions.

Figure 6: Incomplete/Broken Supply Network

Figure 6 clearly demonstrates the incompleteness of the data from the supply chain network where capacity data at resource is missing along with a broken network with respect to missing lanes. Such an incomplete dataset will generate improper planning results.

To avoid the incomplete data flowing into the IBP system, we need to develop interfaces outside the IBP system using ABAP validations in SAP S4 or BW4HANA or CIDS to identify the incompleteness and generate a report for correction by clients IT Team / Data Management Team. By using the "Manage Rules for Master Data Maintenance" feature in IBP, we can effectively define the correct "Subnetwork" node and diagnose which node is disrupting the supply chain network. Example: All Location product combinations to pass through following checks updating a corresponding custom attribute which finally impacts the subnetwork.

1.Inbound: Master data rule to check for Location source in Location Source object.

2.Inbound: Master data rule to check source production in Source Production Header object.

3.Outbound: Master data rule to check Ship-from with product combination in Location Source object.

4.Outbound: Master data rule to check Location Product combination in Source Customer object.

5.Outbound: Master data rule to check Location Product combination in production source Item.

* This is just an approach which may differ from project to project and network schema variations.

4.      Comprehensiveness

Data Comprehensiveness refers to the degree to which all the necessary and relevant data required to support the IBP processes, models, and overall planning objectives is available, accessible, and integrated within the IBP system. It goes beyond just having completeness. It entails:

  • Breadth of Data: Having data across all relevant dimensions and business areas that are within the scope of the IBP implementation. This includes data related to sales, demand, supply, inventory, finance, and potentially other relevant areas.
  • Depth of Data: Having data at the appropriate level of detail required for the planning activities, ensuring that data is available for all the products, customers, locations, and other relevant entities that are included in the IBP planning scope.

Figure 7: Data Comprehensiveness covers all the IBP data objects including each attribute

Example for missing comprehensiveness can be missing key attribute values like Lead Times, Lot Sizes, rounding values, Quota split ratios, Cost rates, On-hand Inventory for few combinations only in IBP system. It may cause unreliable planning results. To systematically capture all such cases, IBP custom alerts can be valuable to report missing attributes. Along with this the IBP’s feature like “Discover Pattern using Machine Learning”, “Find Numerical Outliers” can help identify the completeness gaps.

Figure 8: IBP Feature for data pattern discovery and numeric outliers

5.      Concurrency

Every business executive stives to strike alignment between business strategic planning and execution system. Concurrency in planning and execution represents a paradigm shift from traditional sequential approaches, enabling organizations to adapt dynamically in fast-paced environments. This methodology interweaves planning and action in real time, allowing adjustments based on evolving conditions while maintaining operational continuity. The planning and execution should be coupled like Yin-Yang.

Figure 9: Yin-Yang of Planning and Execution

From IBP planning perspective the concurrency is achieved while keeping it updated with the latest execution data. The execution data represents the latest customer orders, internal goods movements between Plants and RDCs, latest production orders, and vendor related purchase orders are integrated daily or even lesser frequency to IBP. This enables IBP planners to have complete visibility of the execution system, and they can align the plan or coordinate with execution teams to keep working on the same organizational objective.

Conclusive Remarks

At its core, the success of SAP IBP depends entirely on high-quality data. Without a solid foundation of accurate, reliable information, the platform's ability to facilitate collaboration and integrated planning is undermined. This leads to flawed insights, poor decision-making, and ultimately, a failure to deliver the expected business benefits.

Key impacts of poor data quality include:

  • Inaccurate forecasting and supply planning, resulting in issues like over- or under-stocking.

  • Flawed financial planning and projections.

  • Uninformed decisions because the underlying data is inconsistent or incomplete.

  • Friction among teams due to a lack of trust in shared data.

  • Misleading performance metrics, which hinder effective improvement initiatives.

Therefore, prioritizing data quality through robust governance, validation, and monitoring is not just a best practice—it's essential for organizations to fully leverage SAP IBP's potential. The 5C Validation Framework (Conformity, Consistency, Completeness, Comprehensiveness, Concurrency) provides a core set of traits to ensure data is fit for purpose, leading to more reliable insights and greater operational efficiency.

References

    1. Article by Spyrodon D. Tsolas, M.M. Faruque Hsan, “Survivability‐aware design and optimization of distributed supply chain networks in the post COVID‐19 era”, Journal of Advanced Manufacturing and Processing , June 2021
    2. https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/sap-ibp-explained-how-integrated-planning-technology-shaping-pandey-fyarf/
    3. https://learning.sap.com/learning-journeys/exploring-planning-processes-in-sap-ibp/sap-best-practices-for-sap-ibp
    4. https://learning.sap.com/learning-journeys/discovering-sap-ibp-for-inventory-planning-and-optimization/understanding-key-differentiators-of-sap-integrated-business-planning-for-inventory

entry.title: Re: SAC Interview Questions (Basic)
entry.content:
Hi DheerajHJ,

Your SAC Interview Questions (Basic) is very useful for SAC job seekers. However, it would be better to post this content in the Blog section, as that is the right place where community members usually search for such material. If it is posted in the Q&A section, many people may not be able to find it easily, and also the Q&A section is meant only for questions and answers, not for articles.

By posting it in the Blog section, you will also gain more visibility and improve your community rank faster.

entry.title: Re: Conditional Visibility for the inputs in SAP BPA
entry.content:
Hi @kazistov_v ,

I would suggest to go with SAPUI5 based form. This will give you all the flexibility you may need.

Steps

1. Create an Action - Get the information from backend via action.

2. Create a UI5 application for workflow, while creation you would be deciding if its an approval form or not. In the App, creating the form and binding the fields at UI for both data as well the other properties. 

3. Upload to BPA

4. Add as the form in the BPA process.

entry.title: Re: ECC6 upgrade operating system and database
entry.content:
Hi,

As per the screenshot, you are using SAP NW version 7.01 SP level 07. To run Windows 2019 with MS SQL 2019, a minimum SP level of 18 is required, as per SAP Note 2807743. On the existing SAP system, you need to upgrade the SP level and begin migrating the system to a new environment.

Regards

SS
